intro: Eupatorium tucumanense, commonly known as the Tucumán feverfew, is a flowering plant native to Argentina. It belongs to the Asteraceae family and is characterized by its tall, slender stems and clusters of small, white to pale blue flowers. The plant typically grows in dry, open habitats and is adapted to the arid conditions of its native region. It has lance-shaped leaves with serrated edges and produces fluffy, wind-dispersed seeds. Eupatorium tucumanense is often used in traditional medicine for its purported anti-inflammatory and analgesic properties.
